comments.body:
Thank you for your advice. I mean that at this stage, itâ€™s fine to include a link but not directly embed it since itâ€™s supplementary information that people can explore if theyâ€™re interested. Additionally, by including the link, visitors can be directed to your project and might also be interested in checking out the documentation of other projects.

Please include the link under **Introduction â†’ Tips**, right after **Awesome-ChatTTS**, and make sure to add it for every language version.
@fumiama thanks for the fast reply I updated accordingly. Let me know if you like it :). I also added the Note and Tip as translations to the pages that were missing it
I'm not sure why this workflow would have failed but let me know your thoughts.
I will check it. It seems not your fault.
Thanks, when will a new release be done so that "pip check" doesn't show a conflict?
You can upgrade and check it now.

prs.title: python 3.12 fails to install requirements, 3.13 not supported.

comments.body:
I'm using 3.12 for developing fine-tuning branch and find no problem.  
https://github.com/ain-soph/ChatTTS/tree/dev

3.13 is still not supported by many Deep Learning packages. I don't think it shall be supported until upstream packages support it.
Maybe there's something wrong with conda. Sticking to 3.11 in doc can be a hint to user.

4090ä¸Šä½¿ç”¨compile=Trueè€—æ—¶3.3sçš„æ–‡æœ¬ï¼Œç”¨mainåˆ†æ”¯vllmåŠ é€Ÿæ˜¯1.6sï¼Œä¸èƒ½è°ƒæ•´éŸ³è‰²ï¼Œç”¨è¿™ä¸ªprçš„ç‰ˆæœ¬å¯ä»¥è°ƒæ•´ï¼Œä½†é€Ÿåº¦åªæœ‰2.6så·¦å³

I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm.
Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch

also @fumiama for this question

> I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm.
> 
> Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch
> 
> 
> 
> also @fumiama for this question

This part of code is contributed by the community and you can ask @ylzz1997 about that. I'm sorry but I'm not familiar with vLLM ðŸ˜‚.

> I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm. Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch
> 
> also @fumiama for this question

Because Vllm don't suport some feature:
1. custom lm-head
2. multi-codebook sampler (custom sampler)
3. sample without tokenizer

In order for the sampler to support vllm features such as continuous batch and streaming generate, it is necessary to package the post model (lm_cead and others) into vllm schedular. This requires rewriting the VLLM part of the code.

That's all

> > I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm. Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch
> > also @fumiama for this question
> 
> Because Vllm don't suport some feature:
> 
> 1. custom lm-head
> 2. multi-codebook sampler (custom sampler)
> 3. sample without tokenizer
> 
> In order for the sampler to support vllm features such as continuous batch and streaming generate, it is necessary to package the post model (lm_cead and others) into vllm schedular. This requires rewriting the VLLM part of the code.
> 
> That's all

Thanks for your explanation.

> > I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm. Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch
> > also @fumiama for this question
> 
> Because Vllm don't suport some feature:
> 
> 1. custom lm-head
> 2. multi-codebook sampler (custom sampler)
> 3. sample without tokenizer
> 
> In order for the sampler to support vllm features such as continuous batch and streaming generate, it is necessary to package the post model (lm_cead and others) into vllm schedular. This requires rewriting the VLLM part of the code.
> 
> That's all

Yes, we cannot use vllm directly as it requires some code changes. I have implemented a solution here, I am new to Torch and Python, so feel free for any comments.
Only for the llama part: 
Model: https://github.com/niuzheng168/vllm/blob/dev/vllm/model_executor/models/chattts.py 
Sample usage: https://github.com/niuzheng168/vllm/blob/dev/chattts_sample.py

For the issues you list above:

- We can create multiple lm_heads.
- I noticed it [runs slowly](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/issues/8040#issuecomment-2322767368) when we run the sample N times, so I made a lite version of the multi-head sampler.
- This is already supported in vllm by setting detokenize=false.

One of the main challenges is that vllm assumes all the model output is a single token, which is just an int value. However, the TTS system, whether chattts or fishtts, generates multi-head tokens in one decoding step. This means the model output is a token list, breaking the fundamental design. I had to use many if/else statements to ensure the whole pipeline still works.

Overall, compared to moving vllm codes here, implementing a model in vllm will save effort for other features than core model inference, like sampling and scheduling, continual batch processing, etc.
I also reply the road map of [vllm thread](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/issues/5805#issuecomment-2334044900), to see if push vllm support the model official, I believe more and more multi-modal models is using similar model arch, especially for those gpt-4o like models.

> > > I am curious that why we choose move vllm codes to this project, instead of supporting the llm parts in vllm. Supporting the model in vllm will make such feature auto enabled, like streaming generate and continually batch
> > > also @fumiama for this question
> > 
> > 
> > Because Vllm don't suport some feature:
> > 
> > 1. custom lm-head
> > 2. multi-codebook sampler (custom sampler)
> > 3. sample without tokenizer
> > 
> > In order for the sampler to support vllm features such as continuous batch and streaming generate, it is necessary to package the post model (lm_cead and others) into vllm schedular. This requires rewriting the VLLM part of the code.
> > That's all
> 
> Yes, we cannot use vllm directly as it requires some code changes. I have implemented a solution here, I am new to Torch and Python, so feel free for any comments. Only for the llama part: Model: https://github.com/niuzheng168/vllm/blob/dev/vllm/model_executor/models/chattts.py Sample usage: https://github.com/niuzheng168/vllm/blob/dev/chattts_sample.py
> 
> For the issues you list above:
> 
> * We can create multiple lm_heads.
> * I noticed it [runs slowly](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/issues/8040#issuecomment-2322767368) when we run the sample N times, so I made a lite version of the multi-head sampler.
> * This is already supported in vllm by setting detokenize=false.
> 
> One of the main challenges is that vllm assumes all the model output is a single token, which is just an int value. However, the TTS system, whether chattts or fishtts, generates multi-head tokens in one decoding step. This means the model output is a token list, breaking the fundamental design. I had to use many if/else statements to ensure the whole pipeline still works.
> 
> Overall, compared to moving vllm codes here, implementing a model in vllm will save effort for other features than core model inference, like sampling and scheduling, continual batch processing, etc. I also reply the road map of [vllm thread](https://github.com/vllm-project/vllm/issues/5805#issuecomment-2334044900), to see if push vllm support the model official, I believe more and more multi-modal models is using similar model arch, especially for those gpt-4o like models.

Thanks for your great effort. We welcome you to contribute your code into this repo if you like.

yes

> @fengyizhu @fumiama è¯·é—®ä½¿ç”¨ vLLM åŽï¼Œè¿˜èƒ½è¿›è¡Œæ‰¹é‡æŽ¨ç†å—ï¼Ÿ å°±æ˜¯ chat.infer(texts, split_text=Falseï¼‰ä¸­å½“ä¼ å…¥ texts ä¸ºåˆ—è¡¨æ—¶ï¼ŒæŽ¨ç†å‡ºçš„éŸ³é¢‘ä¸º 0s

https://github.com/fengyizhu/ChatTTS-VLLM  ä¿®å¤ç‰ˆ
Why move this down?
No, don't remain this code. It has been moved to embed.py.
Please DO NOT remove the non-vLLM part. The vLLM is always an alternative speed up option since it cannot be used in EVERY devices.
DONOT change the default behavior.

We don't want to introduce `librosa`. Modifying the original code makes sense. ex. replace
```py
keep_cols = np.sum(new_wavs != 0, axis=0) > 0
```
with
```py
# pseudo code without testing, just a hint
keep_cols = np.sum(abs(new_wavs) > 1e-6, axis=0) > 0
```
It's not so good to call into the inner method and you should modify the outer one `gpt.llm.generate`.
If you move a line up, don't change the variable name when it's ok to remain the original one. It will make it difficult to see your changes.

prs.title: fix idx error when do repetition penalty
Fix device mismatch error in embedding loading on branch dev
Update dvae.py and change param gamma to weight

comments.body: This PR fails `#655` unittest, which requires a further check.

The first change in `character_simplier` seems not to be the expected behavior according to `#655` test file, as it requires the refined text still has `?` inside.

I wonder since this `?` is invalid_character, which means it's not seen in training data. Shall we still keep that `?` in inference stage?
After check, it seems both concerns are not expected behaviors. Close this issue.
Also, you can save the str to a txt file (with the ext .pt if you like) and use it just like a .pt file if you like.

> Also, you can save the str to a txt file (with the ext .pt if you like) and use it just like a .pt file if you like.

"use it just like a .pt file if you like" -> You mean we could directly read the tensor via `torch.load()` instead of using `pybase16384` to encode/decode? I didn't know that.

> > Also, you can save the str to a txt file (with the ext .pt if you like) and use it just like a .pt file if you like.
> 
> 
> 
> "use it just like a .pt file if you like" -> You mean we could directly read the tensor via `torch.load()` instead of using `pybase16384` to encode/decode? I didn't know that.

Just treat the str as a kind of binary.
I agree with your changes but as for this name, it'd be better to leave it unchanged.

According to [PEP 8](https://peps.python.org/pep-0008/#method-names-and-instance-variables), 
> Use one leading underscore only for non-public methods and instance variables.

In finetuning case (I change the return type and no-inplace operation for this reason), we need to call this method out of class. Therefore, it's better not to start with a leading underscore if this method is expected to be exposed.
I know your meaning but we want to mark this method as unrecommended. Peopole should always use the str version except for some special reasons.

Yes, that makes sense if there is no plan to add fine-tuning script.
I'm currently working on my [fine-tuning branch](https://github.com/ain-soph/ChatTTS/tree/dev) and it seems to be working to some extent. Will the main repo maintainer consider a PR for supporting fine-tuning?
It sounds great, we will be happy to accept your contribution. As for the fine-tuning, since we will put the codes in the Chat class, it can contain such a internal api directly.

> It sounds great, we will be happy to accept your contribution. As for the fine-tuning, since we will put the codes in the Chat class, it can contain such an internal api directly.

That's where I feel confused. If you want to call `Speaker._sample_random()` method in `Chat` class, then it's an out-of-class call and it means this method is public (i.e., it's still internal w.r.t. this package, but public in terms of the class). If that's the case, it's better to not start with leading underscore if we want to obey the PEP 8 naming standard.

Or do you mean you plan to re-implement such method in `Chat` class instead of calling `Speaker._sample_random()`? That doesn't sound like a good idea to make duplicates.

I see cases for cross-file import for non-class methods with leading underscore ([example](https://github.com/pytorch/vision/blob/f5d9ecd5024d1c4f21a5620cf2cca6d07eabd469/torchvision/prototype/datasets/utils/_resource.py#L21)), but I don't know if it's still the case for out-of-class usage for class methods with leading underscore.

I think we may cc other maintainers for their ideas if there is a disagreement. But anyway, if you make the final decision, I'll make corresponding modification. It's just a small naming concern after all and many packages violate the PEP 8 standard.
Well, in this case, as our main purpose is to prevent users from using this method and the Speaker class is a single instance in Chat, we can regard it as a kind of `static` or `non-class`.

comments.body: è¦æ³¨æ„ä»ŽåŽå¾€å‰åˆ é™¤è¿žç»­çš„0ï¼Œä»¥é¿å…çœŸæ­£çš„ç¼–ç ä¸­ç¡®å®žæœ‰0çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§ï¼ˆè™½ç„¶å°ï¼Œä½†ä¸æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰ï¼‰ã€‚

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> 
>>> array = np.array([[1, 2, 3, 0, 0],
...                   [4, 5, 6, 0, 0],
...                   [0, 0, 0, 0, 0],
...                   [7, 0, 9, 0, 0],
...                   [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]])
>>> 
>>> # Identify rows with non-zero elements using np.any
>>> keep_rows = np.any(array != 0, axis=1)
>>> keep_cols = np.sum(array != 0, axis=0) > 0
>>> # Filter both rows and columns using slicing
>>> result = array[keep_rows, :][:, keep_cols]
>>> 
>>> 
>>> result
array([[1, 2, 3],
       [4, 5, 6],
       [7, 0, 9]])
>>> 



```
ç»´æ•°ä¸èƒ½å˜å•Šï¼Œå°±ç®—ç»™ä¸ª[]æˆ–è€…Noneä¹Ÿè¡Œã€‚å¦å¤–ï¼Œè¯·è§£å†³å†²çªï¼ˆå¯ä»¥å…ˆç”¨æœ€æ–°ç‰ˆä»£ç è¦†ç›–ï¼Œç„¶åŽåŠ ä»¥æ›´æ”¹ï¼‰

> ç»´æ•°ä¸èƒ½å˜å•Šï¼Œå°±ç®—ç»™ä¸ª[]æˆ–è€…Noneä¹Ÿè¡Œã€‚å¦å¤–ï¼Œè¯·è§£å†³å†²çªï¼ˆå¯ä»¥å…ˆç”¨æœ€æ–°ç‰ˆä»£ç è¦†ç›–ï¼Œç„¶åŽåŠ ä»¥æ›´æ”¹ï¼‰

æˆ‘å®žé™…æµ‹è¯•ä¸­æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰é—®é¢˜çš„, æ‰€æœ‰çš„å™ªéŸ³éƒ½æ²¡äº†... æˆ‘æ˜¯æƒ³ 16k çš„å¤§å°, å¦‚æžœæŸä¸ªç»´åº¦å…¨æ˜¯ 0, è¿™ä¸ªç»´åº¦æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æœ¬èº«å°±æœ‰é—®é¢˜

> å¦‚æžœæŸä¸ªç»´åº¦å…¨æ˜¯ 0, è¿™ä¸ªç»´åº¦æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æœ¬èº«å°±æœ‰é—®é¢˜

æ˜¯æœ‰é—®é¢˜ï¼Œä½†ä¸èƒ½é”™ä½ï¼Œè¦ä¸å…¶å®ƒçš„éƒ½å¯¹ä¸ä¸Šä¸‹æ ‡äº†ï¼Œè¿™å°±æŠŠé—®é¢˜æ‰©å¤§äº†ã€‚

> æœ€åŽä¸€è¡Œå…¨ 0 éœ€è¦åˆ ä¹ˆ

ä¸ç”¨ï¼Œå°±è¿™æ ·å°±è¡Œã€‚ðŸ‘
ä¸­é—´æœ‰0æ€Žä¹ˆåŠžå‘¢

å°±æ˜¯æŒ‰ç…§è¿™ä¸ªå®žçŽ°çš„

https://github.com/2noise/ChatTTS/pull/564#issuecomment-2227595065

```
import numpy as np

array = np.array(
[[1, 2, 3, 0, 0],
[4, 5, 6, 0, 0],
[0, 0, 0, 0, 0],
[7, 0, 9, 0, 0],
[7, 0, 9, 2, 0],
[0, 0, 0, 0, 0]]
)

# Identify rows with non-zero elements using np.any
# keep_rows = np.any(array != 0, axis=1)
keep_cols = np.sum(array != 0, axis=0) > 0
# Filter both rows and columns using slicing
result = array[:][:, keep_cols]
print(result)

>>> print(result)
[[1 2 3 0]
 [4 5 6 0]
 [0 0 0 0]
 [7 0 9 0]
 [7 0 9 2]
 [0 0 0 0]]
>>> 
```
OK.

prs.title: Update reademe.md to fix save audio bug in the demo
cmd/jupyteræµå¼ä»£ç ç®€åŒ–ä¼˜åŒ–ï¼›cmd/jupyter stream play example simplify

comments.body:
Maybe you should use
```py
from tools.audio import batch_unsafe_float_to_int16
```
or change it.
No need of `@classmethod`. Maybe you mean `@staticmethod`?
No need of `@classmethod`. Maybe you mean `@staticmethod`?
No need of `@classmethod`. Maybe you mean `@staticmethod`?
No need of `@classmethod`. Maybe you mean `@staticmethod`?
No need of `@classmethod`. Maybe you mean `@staticmethod`?
No need of `@classmethod`. Just use `self`. Then call it after initializing an instance `streamer = ChatStreamer()`
Import pyaudio here, but not below.
You can combine the two examples into one function called `play`, and adjust it with the parameter. Ex. when pass `first_prefill_size=0`, the function will behave the same way as old `example_0`.

Thanks for the suggestion! I tried batch_unsafe_float_to_int16 in tools before and found some problems when running in jit mode.So i make some changes in the example. I can merge it into the tools later.
